content: inside the chamber you find another vat of dissolving body parts suddenly
horrific creature spew forth from the VAT their slimy tentacles grab at your
throats as mouths full of teeth and occur not your flesh hey guys welcome
back to black magic crafts it is October Halloween is approaching and that means
every DM could probably use some new nasty creature to terrify their players
after reviewing the roll maker from green stuff world I was inspired to
create a nasty new monster I broke out my green stuff and my sculpting tools
and I set to work making these disgusting little creatures I don't know
what they are and that doesn't matter I just wanted to build something new and
interesting and gross-looking using that roll maker and I think I
succeeded so let's take a look at how I made these and then at the end of the
video let's figure out what the heck they actually are these creatures were
made almost entirely of green stuff so I had to start by mixing some of that up
one tip to keep in mind when working with this putty is that on the roll the
two parts actually touch in the middle and that means over time that will
create a little strip of cured material that will end up as chunks once you mix
it so it's a good idea to cut out a little strip or the two colors meet
before mixing I began the sculpt with the tentacles to
do this I made small balls of green stuff and rolled them out into little
rods to create an intestine like texture on the putty
I used my roll maker from green stuff Worldcom now I've previously reviewed
this tool in detail if you want to check it out and they gave me a promo code for
my viewers to get a discount when purchasing anything on their site I'll
drop that in the description below now to create the pattern that I wanted I
used a large plate on one side and a small plate on the other this difference
of size will give some interesting variation to the ring sizes and make the
tentacles look more organic rather than machine made it's important to keep some
water on the Roll maker to stop the green stuff from sticking to it I bent
the tentacles into some interesting shapes and left them to cure while I
moved on to sculpting the rest of the monsters I wanted these creatures to
look like puddles of meat that basically only had eyes of mouth and tentacles I
applied a mound of green stuff to my favorite Reaper bases that I use for all
my minis now I would really love to break down all the sculpting steps for
you so you could follow along and recreate your own but that's sort of
impossible to do on this type of a project there isn't a very technical
approach to how I do this and I'm by no means an expert sculptor when doing this
sort of thing I will just grab a sculpting tool and keep shaping the
material until it starts to look how I want a creature like this is very
forgiving there's really no wrong way to do it I created an open mouth use some
microbeads for eyes created a little bit of a tongue and just scratched up the
surface to give the flesh some sort of texture I cut off really tiny tips of
some toothpicks and used them for teeth and I also created little indents in the
putty where I would later be able to glue the
Cole's creating these little recessed spots for the tentacles would make the
connection a lot stronger than just trying to glue them to the surface and
it would also make them look more like they were part of the same body rather
than something that was just tacked on
after the green stuff had all cured a little bit enough that I could handle
the scalps without squishing them I was able to do the fun part of attaching the
tentacles because of my prep work in the sculpting this was a simple matter of
super gluing them in place I prepared my minis for paint by
attaching them to some corks with poster tack and putting them in my cork board
from shifting Lance comm and taking them to the basement to spray them with a
white aerosol primer the weather and Winnipeg is already starting to get
crappy so it's officially annoying to rattle-can things season this is where
the project takes a turn for the frustrating and the video gets a little
bit more interesting I've been trying to learn the art of airbrushing and thought
this project would be a great candidate for using the kit I recently picked up
but as usual since starting using it I ran into problems I barely managed to
get one mini painted before things went well from bad to worse I don't know what
the hell my problem is with this airbrush I bought this the Masters
airbrush kit off of Amazon comes with a compressor comes with the cheap airbrush
other people have used it that it's alright I'm sure the compressor is fine
and I really wanted it to be an awesome viable cheap option that I could
recommend to you guys because it was really affordable but the truth is I've
used this thing only handful of times and every time I fight with it I clean
it really well put water brush cleaner airbrush cleaner through it it's
spraying beautifully the second I use paint within 10 seconds its clogged or
screwed up not spraying I don't know what it is I know air brushes have a
learning curve but you know I'm not stupid and I've been working with tools
for a long time and today this one was really pissing me off
couldn't get it going properly took off the little tip with the little wrench to
try to clean it I went to put it back on and it just snapped so it just it just
broke off and yeah airbrushing has not been going well for me I don't know if I
got a dud or if I did something wrong or if the products actually not good
really disappointing really wanted this to be a good product so yeah what do you
think I want to contact the company see if they'll send me a replacement or what
but anyways just get back to the good old fashioned paintbrush so there's
actually some updates on this I did two things I contacted the manufacturer and
they also reached out to the community for help and recommendations I think
some of the problem that I've been having is because I've been trying to
thin and mix the paint within the cup of the airbrush which is normally fine but
the design of this particular airbrush makes that problematic the company
actually got back to me pretty quickly about my problem but they basically said
too bad so sad you broke a piece it's your own fault buy some new parts I
wasn't really happy with that and I'm not the type of person to invest good
money after bad when it comes to tools so I decided based on the community's
recommendations to try out an Iwata Eclipse after I get my hands on one of
those and play with it for a while I'll let you guys know if the problem turned
out to be the tool or just my fault all along so anyways jumping back to a paint
brush I base coated these guys using vallejo's gourry red this is such a
fantastic color it's so vibrant and it perfectly emulates a demonic bag of
flesh next I gave them a wash using citadel's egg racks earth shades this is
a really lazy way to bring out all the details in a sculpt
I painted the eyes using Vallejo Sun yellow and the teeth with vallejo's bone
white I also applied some sepia wash to the teeth to make them a little bit more
gnarly and yellow looking i repainted the ring of the bases using a basic
black craft paint I find this step really important to finish a piece off
you could of course choose to paint out the base the same color as the creatures
but I enjoyed the way the distinct black based separation looks to me it's kind
of like a picture frame around a painting I wanted these things to look
proper gross and slimy so I didn't coat them using my usual matte varnish
instead i coated them in a gloss varnish
to add even more gross Ness I'm ick stuff some five-minute epoxy with a bit
of gory red paint I applied this to the minis and gave it a few minutes to start
to cure using a sacrificial brush I created some smears and tendrils of
bloody goo
and while I wanted the minis to look wet and shiny I did not want the black ring
of the base to be so glossy I gave that a coat of brush on Vallejo matte varnish
since it would be difficult to mask and spray just the base
I think these turned out really great and this type of creature is an ideal
starting place for anyone wanting to try their hand at miniature sculpting for
the first time you could make these tentacles without the roll maker tool
I've heard of people successfully using hair combs instead but the roll maker
definitely makes it easier again I'll put a link to it and the promo code in
the video description this video was not sponsored by green stuff world I was
just really inspired by using the tool if you want to pick up any other
crafting supplies check out black magic crafts CA that's where I have links to
all of the stuff that I use and recommend and buying through those
affiliate links helps fund these videos if you really like what I do and you
want to help me keep doing it the best way you can do that is by supporting
black magic crafts on patreon those funds play a major role in allowing me
to put out regular content and focus all of my efforts into this channel check it
out I'd love to have you as the newest member of the black magic crafts
fellowship well disgusting monster sculpt complete
I think it is a success I'm pretty happy with these but what are they what are
these creatures are they weird flesh-eating demons are they monsters
made of humanoid intestines and body parts by a mad wizard I don't know they
could be any manner of creatures to suit the theme of your game originally I
thought that I would stack these out and share those stats with you guys but I
think you can probably come up with something even cooler than me so I would
like you all to comment below with what this
creature is even if you just want to give it a name and a story and maybe
some abilities or if you want to stat it out go nuts
I'd really like to see what you guys come up with and I'm sure all the
viewers would love to read through the various comments to find something
inspiring from within them I like these these are freaking cool
I'll see you guys again next week Cheers
